content.text: Infected pancreatic necrosis is a serious complication of acute pancreatitis, associated with high morbidity and mortality. It occurs when parts of the pancreas die and become infected, usually with gut-derived organisms.

The diagnosis of infected pancreatic necrosis is suspected in patients with pancreatitis who deteriorate or fail to improve after 7-10 days of hospitalization. CT-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) for Gram stain and culture is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management involves supportive care, antibiotics, and often drainage or debridement of the necrotic tissue. A step-up approach, starting with percutaneous or endoscopic drainage followed by minimally invasive surgical debridement if needed, is often preferred.

appliesTo.description: Patients with confirmed or suspected infected pancreatic necrosis

components.drug: Carbapenems (e.g., imipenem, meropenem) or a combination of a broad-spectrum cephalosporin and metronidazole

regimenData.notes: Antibiotics should be tailored based on culture results. Antifungal therapy should be considered in patients with prolonged antibiotic use or other risk factors for fungal infection.
